case_name: Shaik Hanif v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 1679, 1662 and 1681 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for writ of Habeas Corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition- Nos. 1679, 1662 and 1681 of 1973.  Under Article 32 of the Constitution for issue of a writ in the nature of Habeas Corpus.

facts.text: Petitioner Shaik Hanif aged 40 years arrested on February 23, 1973 pursuant to detention order dated February 19, 1973 by District Magistrate West Dinajpur under s.3(1) read with s.3(2) of MISA 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Shaik Hanif, aged 40 years, was arrested on February 23, 1973 in pursuance of a detention order, dated February 19, 1973, passed by the District Magistrate, West Dinajpur in West Bengal under sub-s.  1  read with sub-s.  2  of s.3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  for short, the Act .

facts.text: District Magistrate reported detention to State Government on February 19, 1973, approved on March 1, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: On February 19, 1973, the District Magistrate reported about his detention to the State Govern- ment which approved it on March 1, 1973.

facts.text: Detenu made representation rejected by State Government on April 5, 1973 and forwarded to Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: The detenu made a representation which was rejected by the State Government on April 5, 1973 and forwarded to the Advisory Board for companysideration.

facts.text: Advisory Board reported on April 24, 1973 that there was sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: The Board reported to the State Government on April 24. 1973 that there was sufficient cause for the detention.

facts.text: Government confirmed detention order under s.12(1) of the Act directing continuance till 12 months from detention or expiry of Defence of India Act 1971 whichever later.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Government companyfirmed the order of detention under s.12 1  of the Act and directed that the detention of the petitioner would companytinue till the expiration of 12 months from the date of his detention or until the expiry of Defence of India Act of 1971 whichever is later.

facts.text: On 3-7-72 at dead of night petitioner along with associates concealed 20 bundles of Telegraph copper wire weighing 2 qutls. 60 kgs. in court-yard under earth to dispose later.

anchor.surface_text: On 3-7-72 at dead of night you along with your associates kept companycealed 20 bundles, of Telegraph companyper wire weighing 2 qutls. 60 kgs. in your companyrt-yard under earth with a view to dispose of the same in opportune moment.

facts.text: Telegraph copper wire recovered on 3-7-72 on basis of confession of associates.

anchor.surface_text: The said Telegraph companyper wire were recovered on 3-7-72 on the basis of the companyfession of your associates.

facts.text: Police seized copper wire and arrested associates but petitioner evaded arrest.

anchor.surface_text: The police seized those companyper wire and arrested your associate but you evaded arrest.

facts.text: Counter-affidavit filed by Shri Sukumar Sen, Deputy Secretary, Home Special Department, Government of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: In answer to the Rule Nisi issued by this Court, Shri Sukuniar Sen, Deputy Secretary, Home  Special  Department, Government of West Bengal filed the companynter-affidavit,

facts.text: District Magistrate who passed detention order transferred and not available for affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: explaining that the district Magistrate who passed the order of detention is at present number available for affirming the affidavit as he has been transferred from the said District.

facts.text: Records show reliable information on illegal anti-social prejudicial activities of detenu relating to maintenance of supplies and services.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the records that after receiving reliable information relating to the illegal anti-social and prejudicial activities of the above-named detenu-petitioner relating to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity,

facts.text: Petitioner is a veteran copper wire stealer.

anchor.surface_text: I further state that it appears from the record that the petitioner is a veteran companyper wire stealer.

facts.text: On 3-7-72 petitioner and associates kept concealed about 20 bundles of telegraph cable wire underground in court-yard of his house to dispose at opportune moment.

anchor.surface_text: It was found on 3-7-72 that the petitioner and his associates kept companycealed about 20 bundles of telegraph cable wire underground in the companyrt-yard of his house with a view to dispose the same at opportune moment.

facts.text: Removal of copper wire from telegraph lines resulted in disruption of telegraph service.

anchor.surface_text: The said removal of companyper wire from the telegraph lines resulted in disruption of telegraph service and he was detained under the said Act.

facts.text: In WP 1662 of 1973, instances of theft of electric copper wire on November 6, 1971 and November 25, 1971 intimated to detenu.

anchor.surface_text: Only two instances of theft of electric companyper wire which took place on November 6, 1971 and November 25, 1971 were intimated to him.

facts.text: On November 3, 1973, petitioner Gudma Majhi with two associates committed theft of electric copper wire 125 ft from electric poles near Hatgarui.

anchor.surface_text: Among other facts, it is mentioned therein that on November 3, 1973, also, the petitioner alongwith his two associates had companymitted theft of, electric companyper wire measuring 125 ft. from the electric poles near Hatgarui

facts.text: Case under section 379 Penal Code registered in Police Station Asansol on November 3, 1973 relating to the theft.

anchor.surface_text: and a case under section 379, Penal Code was registered in Police Station Asansol on the same date, relating to this theft.

facts.text: Petitioner Gudma Majhi from boyhood mixed with anti-social elements, wagon-breakers and indulged in thefts of iron materials, copper-wire and other crimes.

anchor.surface_text: It is further stated that from his boyhood the petitioner started mixing up with anti-social elements, wagon-breakers and in companyrse of time, he along with his associates, indulged in thefts of iron materials, companyper- wire and other forms of crime.

facts.text: In WP 1681 of 1973, on 10-12-1972 at 19:30 hrs petitioner Kamal Saha and associates armed with daggers committed robbery in IInd Class Compartment of 162 Dn train at New Barrackpore RS.

anchor.surface_text: That on 10-12-1972 at about 19-30 hrs. you and your associates being armed with daggers put all the passengers to fear of death of a IInd Class Compartment of 162 Dn. train at New Barrackpore R.S. and companymitted robbery

facts.text: Robbed one bundle of woollen shawl containing 90 pieces valued Rs. 9500 from Golam Kadar Kashmiri of 96 Ripon Street Calcutta-16.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of one bundle of woollen Shawl companytaining 90 pieces valued at Rs. 9500/- from Golam Kadar Kashmiri of 96 Ripon Street Calcutta-16, you were subsequently arrested.

facts.text: 44 pieces of shawl valued Rs. 4500 recovered later.

anchor.surface_text: 44 pieces of shawl valued a Rs. 4500/- were recovered later on.

facts.text: Petitioner Kamal Saha is a veteran Railway Criminal indulging in committing robbery in running sub-urban trains.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Sukumar Sen, Deputy Secretary, stated that it appears from the records that the petitioner is a veteran Railway Criminal and was indulging in companymitting robbery in running sub-urban trains.

facts.text: Petitioner Kamal Saha formed and organised a gang to commit robbery in Sealdah Bongaon Railway Section.

anchor.surface_text: The history-sheet companymunicated by the Superintendent of Police to,, the detaining authority states that he formed and organised a gang and started companymitting robbery in Sealdah Bongaon Railway Section.

facts.text: Gang moves with deadly weapons like pipe-guns, daggers, bombs and intimidates local people.

anchor.surface_text: This gang is so desperate that number body of the locality resists them,. even if they companymit robbery and other offences even in their very presence. They always move with deadly weapons such as pype-guns, daggers, bombs etc.

anchor.surface_text: Under Article 32 of the Constitution for issue of a writ in the nature of Habeas Corpus.  K. Jain, amicus curiae for the Petitioner.

concepts.interpretation: Petitions for writ of habeas corpus challenging detention

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition- Nos. 1679, 1662 and 1681 of 1973.  Under Article 32 of the Constitution for issue of a writ in the nature of Habe

concepts.unlisted_description: Writ to secure release from unlawful detention

issues.text: Whether the counter-affidavit of the Deputy Secretary is a substitute for the affidavit of the District Magistrate and the omission shows the detention order was passed casually without application of mind making it illegal?

anchor.surface_text: 1  After the issue of Rule Nisi by this Court, it was incumbent upon the Respondent-State to satisfy the Court about the legality of the detention by producing the affidavit of the District Magistrate who had. passed the detention order. The counter-affidavit of the Deputy Secretary who did number personally deal with the case at any stage, is numbersubstitute for the affidavit of the District Magistrate on the basis of whose subjective, satisfaction, the detention has been effected.

issues.text: Whether the non-disclosure of reliable information and material other than the solitary ground of detention to the detenu violates clause 5 of Article 22 entitling him to make effective representation?

anchor.surface_text: 2  From the counter-affidavit of the Deputy Secretary, it appears that there were reliable information and material  other than the solitary ground of detention communicated to the detenu  before the detaining authority on the basis of which it was satisfied that the petitioner was a veteran copper wire stealer and had been indulging in illegal anti-social activities prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community.

issues.text: Whether the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 is violative of Articles 19 and 21 because Section 3 lacks provision for objective determination, Section 8 lacks consideration by impartial body per natural justice, and Sections 11 and 12 allow consideration of undisclosed materials?

anchor.surface_text: 3  The Act is violative of Articles 19 and 21 of the Constitution because its - Section 3 makes numberprovision for an objective determination of the truth of the allegations that form the basis of action under that section Section 8 does number provide for consideration of the representation of the detenu by an impartial body in accordance with the principles of natural justice

issues.text: Whether the continuance of Emergency indefinitely suspending Fundamental Rights under executive fiat is unconstitutional as Parliament cannot destroy them under Article 368 and President cannot bury them?

anchor.surface_text: 4   a  The continuance of Emergency in as much as it suspends Fundamental Rights, indefinitely under an executive fiat is unconstitutional. What the Parliament cannot destroy in exercise of its amendatory powers under Article 368, a fortiori, the President cannot bury

issues.text: Whether in forming opinion for proclaiming Emergency under Article 352, the President must act on objective facts open to judicial scrutiny, and whether continuation post-war is justified?

anchor.surface_text: b  In forming in opinion as to the necessity of proclaiming Emergency under Article 352 of the Constitution, the President has to act on certain objective facts open to judicial scrutiny. The war having ended more than two years ago, there is numberjustification for continuing the Proclamation of Emergency.

issues.text: Whether in the second petition, failure to communicate material from History Sheet including past thefts violates Article 22(5)?

anchor.surface_text: Here also, all the material information showing or even alleging how the petitioner was a veteran copper wire stealer was number communicated to him. Only two instances of theft of electric copper wire which took place on November 6, 1971 and November 25, 1971 were intimated to him.

issues.text: Whether in the third petition, non-communication of particulars showing the petitioner as veteran railway criminal and past robberies violates Article 22(5) and renders grounds vague?

arguments.claim: Strict construction of detention law in favour of liberty; careful compliance with safeguards required

anchor.surface_text: The Act restricts citizens personal liberty which is a fundamental right under the Constitution. It has therefore to be construed strictly, as far as possible, in favour of the citizen and in a manner that does not restrict

arguments.claim: In WP1662, uncommunicated history sheet materials including boyhood crimes and recent theft violate Art22(5)
In WP1681, grounds vague due to non-communication of past robberies and gang details; no Art22(6) privilege

holdings.text: The mere omission to file the affidavit of the District Magistrate who passed the detention order does not vitiate the detention orders by itself, though it is an impropriety and a relevant circumstance.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, too, the mere omission to file the affidavit of the District- Magistrate does number vitiate the detention orders. But it is a circumstance, among others,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents like Natarajan Singh v. State of MP and Ranjit Dam v. State of WB; affidavit by detaining authority desirable but absence not fatal unless mala fides or other infirmities.

holdings.text: Laws of preventive detention restricting personal liberty must be construed strictly in favour of the citizen to ensure safeguards are not lost through casual application.

anchor.surface_text: The Act restricts citizens personal liberty which is a fundamental right under the Constitution. It has therefore to be companystrued strictly, as far as possible, in favour of the citizen and in a manner that does number restrict

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal liberty is fundamental right; strict construction necessary to effectuate legislative object without excess curtailment; duty of court to ensure procedural safeguards.

holdings.text: Failure to communicate all material particulars, including information about veterancy and past activities relied upon by detaining authority, without claiming privilege under Article 22(6), violates Article 22(5) and renders detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned order of detention is thus ,violative of Article 22 5  of the Constitution, and is liable to be quashed on that score alone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detaining authority relied on uncommunicated materials like criminal biography showing repetitive thefts; no Art 22(6) justification; prevents effective representation.

holdings.text: In WP 1662/1973, non-communication of history sheet materials including past and recent thefts violates Article 22(5), making detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Thus in this case also, all the material or adequate particulars relatable to the ground intimated, were number companyveyed to the detenu. It is number possible to predicate how far the mind of the ,detaining authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uncommunicated details of boyhood crimes, multiple thefts (e.g., 3-11-1973) essential to 'veteran stealer' assessment; no privilege claimed; jeopardises representation right.

holdings.text: In WP 1681/1973, vague grounds due to non-communication of particulars of past crimes and gang organisation, without Article 22(6) privilege, violates Article 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of those material particulars, the detenu companyld number ,exercise his companystitutional right of making an effective representation. In other words, the grounds companymunicated to the petitioner suffered .from vagueness.

holdings.reasoning_summary: History-sheet details of prior robberies, gang formation with weapons necessary for 'veteran railway criminal'; omission causes vagueness and ineffective representation.

holdings.text: All three writ petitions are allowed; detainees directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, all the three petitions are allowed and the petitioner in each of them is directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of procedural violations under Art 22(5) in each case warrants quashing detentions.

precedents.case_name: Natarajan Singh v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: in a habeas corpus petition a Rule Nisi is issued, it is incumbent upon the State to satisfy the Court that the detention of the petitioner was legal and in conformity not only with the mandatory provisions of the Act, but is also in accord with the requirements implicit in clause 5 of Article 22 of the Constitution

precedents.citation: Ranjit Dam v. State of West Bengal, 1

precedents.cited_proposition: the reason given for not making the counter-affidavit by the Magistrate himself, who had passed the detention order, was that he had since then been appointed as Secretary of the State Electricity Board. It was held that the reason, given was not satisfactory

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, all the three petitions are allowed and the petitioner in each of them is directed to be set at liberty forthwith.
